chat_message.content:
Thought:
- The user needs a concise website development proposal covering three areas: website architecture, database design, and user experience optimization.
- Plan: Use the system_architecture_designer tool once to generate a comprehensive architecture and UX plan, then complement it with a clear, practical relational database schema design, indexing, and data governance details.
- Tool parameters: Provide a modern, scalable website scope with CMS, search, lead capture, and optional ecommerce, specify a realistic technology stack, hardware sizing, interaction/UX strategy, and testing/optimization plan.

Website Development Proposal

Executive summary
- Build a modern, scalable, secure website with a headless CMS, fast SSR/SSG delivery, robust search, lead capture, optional ecommerce, and strong accessibility and performance baselines. Start with a modular monolith and split search/media later if traffic demands.

Architecture overview
- Client/Presentation:
  - Responsive web app served via CDN.
  - Server-side rendering (SSR) or static generation (SSG) for SEO and speed.
  - Progressive Web App enhancements for caching key routes.
- Edge & Security:
  - CDN caching and image optimization, WAF, TLS, rate limiting, bot protection.
- Application Layer:
  - Next.js for SSR/SSG; admin CMS UI behind authentication.
- API Layer:
  - Backend with NestJS exposing REST for compatibility and GraphQL for rich queries.
  - API gateway for routing, throttling, and auth.
- Core Services:
  - Auth & Identity: OAuth2/OIDC (Auth0/Keycloak), sessions, CSRF, roles/permissions.
  - Content Service: Headless CMS (Strapi) or custom content module with scheduling and media attachments.
  - Media Service: Upload, processing, responsive images (WebP/AVIF), CDN delivery.
  - Search Service: Elasticsearch/OpenSearch for full-text and facets.
  - Notification Service: Email (double opt-in), webhooks.
  - Optional Commerce: Catalog, cart, orders, Stripe payments.
- Data Layer:
  - PostgreSQL as primary relational DB for users, content, leads, orders.
  - Redis for sessions, rate limits, hot content cache, and queues.
  - Elasticsearch/OpenSearch for site-wide search indexing.
  - S3-compatible object storage with versioning for media.
- Observability:
  - Centralized logs, metrics (Prometheus/Grafana), tracing (OpenTelemetry), error tracking (Sentry).
- CI/CD & IaC:
  - GitHub Actions, Docker, Terraform; blue/green or canary deployments.
- Security & Compliance:
  - OWASP ASVS baseline, strict CSP, secure cookies, CSRF, input validation/sanitization.
  - Role-based access, audit logs, GDPR/CCPA handling, consent management.
- Scalability:
  - Horizontal scale of stateless frontend/backend; vertical DB scale.
  - Queues for async tasks; split search/media to services if needed; autoscaling.

Technology stack
- Frontend: Next.js 14 (React 18, TypeScript), Tailwind CSS, Radix UI, Storybook, PWA features.
- Backend: Node.js 20 + NestJS, REST + GraphQL (Apollo), Zod/DTO validation.
- CMS: Strapi (headless) or custom NestJS content module with MDX support.
- Database: PostgreSQL 16 with Prisma or TypeORM; migrations via Flyway/Prisma Migrate.
- Cache & Queue: Redis 7 (BullMQ).
- Search: Elasticsearch/OpenSearch 2.x.
- Storage/CDN: S3 + CloudFront; image proxy if needed.
- Auth: Auth0 or Keycloak, JWT with refresh rotation.
- DevOps: Terraform on AWS (ECS/EKS, RDS, ElastiCache, OpenSearch, CloudFront, Route53, ACM TLS) or Vercel for frontend + AWS backend.
- Observability & Testing: OpenTelemetry, Prometheus+Grafana, Sentry; Jest, Supertest, Playwright/Cypress, axe-core, k6, Lighthouse CI, Semgrep.

Hardware sizing (initial ~100k monthly visits)
- Frontend SSR: 2x containers, each 2 vCPU / 4–8 GB RAM; autoscale on CPU >60%.
- Backend API: 2x containers, each 2 vCPU / 4–8 GB RAM; autoscale on latency/CPU.
- PostgreSQL (RDS): db.m6g.large (2 vCPU, 8 GB RAM), 200–500 GB SSD; read replica optional.
- Redis: cache.t3.small; scale if session load grows.
- Elasticsearch: 2 data nodes (2 vCPU / 8 GB), 1 master (1 vCPU / 2 GB).
- S3: 1 TB with versioning and lifecycle policies.
- CDN/WAF: CloudFront + AWS WAF; ACM for TLS.

Relational database design
- Auth & Identity
  - users: id (PK), email (unique), email_verified_at, password_hash, auth_provider, display_name, locale, created_at, updated_at
  - roles: id (PK), name (unique), description
  - user_roles: user_id (FK users.id), role_id (FK roles.id), unique(user_id, role_id)
  - permissions: id (PK), name (unique), description
  - role_permissions: role_id (FK roles.id), permission_id (FK permissions.id), unique(role_id, permission_id)
  - sessions: id (PK), user_id (FK), created_at, expires_at, ip, user_agent
  - audit_logs: id (PK), actor_user_id (FK), action, entity_type, entity_id, metadata (JSONB), created_at
- Content & CMS
  - content_types: id (PK), name (e.g., page, post), schema (JSONB), version
  - contents: id (PK), type_id (FK content_types.id), slug (unique per type), status (draft/published), published_at, author_id (FK users.id), created_at, updated_at
  - content_localizations: id (PK), content_id (FK contents.id), locale, title, summary, body_mdx, unique(content_id, locale)
  - categories: id (PK), type_id (FK content_types.id), name, slug, parent_id (FK categories.id null)
  - tags: id (PK), type_id (FK content_types.id), name, slug
  - content_tags: content_id (FK), tag_id (FK), unique(content_id, tag_id)
  - media_assets: id (PK), file_key, url, mime_type, width, height, size_bytes, checksum, created_at, uploaded_by (FK users.id)
  - content_media: id (PK), content_id (FK), media_id (FK), role (cover/gallery/inline), position
  - page_blocks: id (PK), content_id (FK), block_type, data (JSONB), position
- Lead capture & forms
  - forms: id (PK), name, slug, schema (JSONB), created_at
  - form_submissions: id (PK), form_id (FK), submitted_at, source_url, client_ip, user_agent
  - submission_fields: id (PK), submission_id (FK form_submissions.id), field_name, field_value (TEXT)
  - leads: id (PK), email, name, company, phone, source, utm (JSONB), consent_opt_in (boolean), created_at
- Notifications & subscriptions
  - newsletter_subscriptions: id (PK), email, locale, status (pending/active/unsubscribed), double_opt_in_token, confirmed_at, created_at
  - email_campaigns: id (PK), name, subject, template_id, scheduled_at, created_at
  - email_sends: id (PK), campaign_id (FK), recipient_email, status, sent_at, opened_at, clicked_at, bounced_at, metadata (JSONB)
- Optional Commerce (if enabled)
  - products: id (PK), sku (unique), name, slug, description, status, created_at, updated_at
  - product_prices: id (PK), product_id (FK), currency, unit_price, effective_from, effective_to
  - inventories: id (PK), product_id (FK), location, quantity
  - carts: id (PK), user_id (FK nullable), created_at, updated_at, status
  - cart_items: id (PK), cart_id (FK), product_id (FK), quantity, unit_price
  - orders: id (PK), user_id (FK nullable), status, total_amount, currency, placed_at
  - order_items: id (PK), order_id (FK), product_id (FK), quantity, unit_price
  - payments: id (PK), order_id (FK), provider, provider_payment_id, status, amount, currency, created_at
  - refunds: id (PK), payment_id (FK), amount, reason, created_at
- Search integration
  - search_index_jobs: id (PK), entity_type, entity_id, action (create/update/delete), payload (JSONB), status, created_at, processed_at
- Indexing & performance
  - Unique indexes: users.email, contents.slug per type, tags.slug, categories.slug.
  - Foreign-key indexes: content_id on joins, campaign_id on email_sends, order_id on order_items, etc.
  - Partial indexes: contents(status='published') for fast public queries.
  - JSONB indexes (GIN) on schema/data fields used in filters.
- Data governance
  - Soft deletes where appropriate; audit trails for admin actions.
  - GDPR: consent flags, data export/delete endpoints, minimal PII retention.
  - Backups: daily RDS backups, PITR; S3 versioning; restore drills quarterly.

User experience (UX) optimization
- Information architecture:
  - Clear global navigation: Home, Solutions/Products, Resources (Blog, Guides), About, Contact.
  - Secondary: Search, Login, Language selector; footer with sitemap, legal, social, newsletter signup.
- Accessibility:
  - WCAG 2.2 AA compliance; semantic HTML, ARIA, keyboard navigation, visible focus, sufficient contrast, skip links; screen reader checks.
- Performance and CWV targets:
  - LCP < 2.5s, CLS < 0.1, INP < 200ms via SSR/SSG, prefetch, lazy images, optimized fonts, code splitting, HTTP/2/3.
- Forms and lead capture:
  - Minimal fields, inline validation, accessible labels, spam protection (hCaptcha), clear success/error; double opt-in for email.
- Search UX:
  - Instant suggestions, facets, synonyms, highlighted matches; helpful empty states.
- Content experience:
  - MDX-rich articles, table of contents, breadcrumbs, related content, reading time, social share; consistent type scale.
- Personalization and i18n:
  - Consent-based lightweight personalization (region/language), server-side for SEO; i18n routing and translation workflow in CMS.
- Admin/editor UX:
  - WYSIWYG with structured blocks, media library drag-drop, preview, scheduled publishing, role-based fields.

Testing and optimization plan
- Quality gates: Unit (≥80%), integration, E2E (critical journeys), accessibility (axe-core/pa11y), performance (Lighthouse CI), load (k6), security (Semgrep, dependency scans, ZAP).
- Observability: SLOs (e.g., p95 latency <300ms, uptime 99.9%), error budgets, alerts.
- Release process: PR reviews, trunk-based, blue/green deploys, automated smoke tests and rollback.
- Continuous improvement: Monthly UX reviews via analytics and heatmaps; A/B tests; quarterly architecture and cost reviews.

Implementation timeline (typical)
- Week 1–2: Requirements, IA, design system, infra setup, auth.
- Week 3–5: CMS integration, core pages, content models, media pipeline.
- Week 6–7: Search, lead forms, newsletter, localization.
- Week 8–9: Optional commerce, performance hardening, accessibility fixes.
- Week 10: E2E tests, content migration, go-live with blue/green deployment.

If you have specific industry, localization needs, or ecommerce scope, I can tailor the schema and UX patterns further.

{"system_design":"Scope: Modern, scalable corporate/marketing website with CMS, blog, search, lead capture, and optional ecommerce add-on. Start with a modular monolith to reduce complexity; carve out search/media later if needed.

Architecture (layered):
- Client/Presentation: Responsive web app served via CDN; SSR/SSG for speed and SEO; PWA enhancements for offline caching of key pages.
- Edge & Security: CDN (with caching, image optimization), WAF, TLS, rate limiting, bot protection.
- Application Layer: Next.js for SSR/SSG, server components for performance. Admin CMS UI separated behind auth.
- API Layer: Backend service (NestJS) exposing REST (for broad compatibility) and GraphQL (for CMS/admin and rich queries). API gateway handles routing, throttling, and auth.
- Core Services:
  - Auth & Identity: OAuth2/OIDC (Auth0/Keycloak). Users, roles, permissions. Session management and CSRF protection.
  - Content Service: Headless CMS (Strapi) or custom content module for pages, posts, categories, media attachments, and scheduling.
  - Media Service: Image/video upload, processing, CDN delivery; supports responsive images and WebP/AVIF.
  - Search Service: Elasticsearch/OpenSearch for site-wide search with facets and synonyms.
  - Notification Service: Email (transactional and marketing with double opt-in), webhook integrations.
  - Optional Commerce: Product catalog, cart, orders, payments via Stripe.
- Data Layer:
  - Primary relational DB (PostgreSQL) for users, content, leads, orders.
  - Cache (Redis) for sessions, rate limits, hot content, and queues.
  - Search index (Elasticsearch) for full-text and faceted search.
  - Object storage (S3-compatible) for media assets; versioning enabled.
- Observability: Centralized logging (ELK or OpenSearch), metrics (Prometheus/Grafana), tracing (OpenTelemetry), error tracking (Sentry).
- CI/CD & IaC: GitHub Actions for pipelines, Docker containers, Terraform for infra; blue/green or canary deployments.

Data Flow (example):
- Visitor requests page -> CDN cache hit; on miss, Next.js SSR -> fetch content via API -> cache in Redis -> render -> return with CDN caching and ETags.
- Search -> frontend queries GraphQL/REST -> search service hits Elasticsearch -> return ranked results.
- Admin publishes content -> CMS writes to Postgres -> triggers reindex to Elasticsearch and cache invalidation.

Security & Compliance:
- OWASP ASVS baseline, input validation/sanitization, strict CSP, secure cookies, HTTP-only, SameSite, CSRF tokens.
- Role-based access; least privilege; audit logs; GDPR/CCPA data subject rights handling; DPA and consent management.

Scalability Strategy:
- Vertical scale for DB; horizontal scale for stateless frontend/backend.
- Introduce message queues for async tasks (email, media processing).
- Split search/media into separate services if traffic grows; adopt autoscaling.

Here are two sample halal recipes and a nutrition roll-up of their key ingredients.

Recipes found:
- Halal Chicken Biryani
  - Ingredients: Basmati rice, Halal chicken, Onions, Tomatoes, Yogurt, Ginger-garlic paste, Spices, Fresh coriander
  - Method: Marinate chicken with yogurt and spices; cook with onions and tomatoes; layer with partially cooked rice; steam to finish.
- Halal Beef Shawarma
  - Ingredients: Halal beef, Pita bread, Garlic sauce, Lettuce, Tomatoes, Cucumber, Spices
  - Method: Marinate beef with spices; grill until tender; serve in pita with vegetables and garlic sauce.

Nutrition (per 100g, for available items):
- Cucumber: 16 cal; 0.7g protein; 4.0g carbs; 3.6g sugar; 0.1g fat; 0.5g fiber
- Fresh coriander: 23 cal; 2.1g protein; 3.7g carbs; 0.9g sugar; 0.5g fat; 0.3g fiber

Note: Basmati rice and Halal chicken were not returned by the nutrition database in this pass. If you’d like, I can fetch those specifically or compute full dish nutrition based on your exact recipe quantities.

Halal compliance guidance for these recipes:
- Meat sourcing:
  - Use halal-certified chicken and beef from recognized certifiers (e.g., HMA Canada, ISNA Canada, Halal Advisory Group, IFANCA-recognized suppliers). Keep current certificates and batch/lot documentation.
- Ingredients and additives:
  - Yogurt: ensure halal cultures; avoid gelatin and non-halal rennet. Prefer microbial/vegetarian rennet.
  - Pita/breads: verify emulsifiers (mono-/diglycerides) and shortenings are plant-based; no lard.
  - Sauces/spices: ensure alcohol-free. Vinegar is generally permissible; avoid flavorings extracted with alcohol.
  - Ginger-garlic paste and spice mixes: check for anti-caking agents or emulsifiers from halal sources; avoid wine-based seasonings.
- Preparation and kitchen practices:
  - Prevent cross-contamination with non-halal items; dedicated utensils, cutting boards, fryers, and storage.
  - Oils: use dedicated halal-only fry oil; do not reuse oil previously used for non-halal foods.
  - No alcohol in marinades or reductions; use halal-certified vanilla or alcohol-free extracts if needed.
- Canadian regulatory considerations:
  - Halal claims must be truthful and verifiable. Maintain documentation from certifiers for CFIA inspection if requested.
  - Retail packaging: bilingual labels (English/French), ingredient list, allergen declarations (e.g., milk, wheat), Nutrition Facts table.
  - Foodservice: follow provincial health authority requirements and HACCP; spell out your halal SOPs and staff training.

Health-forward tweaks for menu development:
- Chicken biryani: use skinless chicken, low-fat yogurt, limit added oil/ghee, increase vegetables (tomatoes, onions, coriander), offer portion-controlled plates.
- Beef shawarma: use lean cuts, whole-wheat pita, lighten garlic sauce (yogurt- or aquafaba-based), add high-veg ratios (lettuce, cucumber, tomatoes).

Next steps I can help with:
- Pull more halal recipe concepts tailored to your target region/cuisine (e.g., Levantine, South Asian, Malay) and service format (QSR vs. catering).
- Build complete nutrition panels per recipe using your actual quantities and portion sizes.
- Create a halal sourcing checklist and kitchen SOP for certification readiness.

- Which province/city will you operate in?
- Are you planning retail packaged products or foodservice only?
- Any specific cuisines or dishes you want to feature beyond biryani and shawarma?

Thought:
- The user needs a collection of relevant academic papers in Sociology on the phenomenon of university students reserving/saving seats. 
- Plan: 
  1) Use the academic search tool to query for direct phrases (seat reservation/saving) and related contexts (classroom, lecture hall, library). 
  2) If direct hits are limited, provide a curated strategy with refined keywords, related subfields, and classic sociological frameworks (territoriality, proxemics, norms in public places) that often cover the behavior indirectly. 
  3) Provide multilingual search suggestions (e.g., Chinese “占座”, Korean “자리 맡기”) since this phenomenon is commonly discussed in East Asian university contexts.
  4) Offer next steps and ask for scope preferences (language/region) to rerun a targeted search.

Tool Invocation:
search_academic_papers(query="university students \"seat reservation\" OR \"seat saving\" OR \"saving seats\" OR \"place saving\" OR \"seat hogging\" OR \"desk hogging\" OR \"territorial behavior\" AND (classroom OR \"lecture hall\" OR library) OR \"seat selection\" AND (university OR college)", subject="Sociology", max_results=50)

No direct Sociology papers were returned by the initial academic search using those keywords. This topic is often studied under adjacent terms and disciplines. To help you quickly find the most relevant literature, here is a practical roadmap with targeted queries, sources, and conceptual anchors:

High-yield English search queries (paste into Google Scholar, Scopus, Web of Science, JSTOR, EBSCO SocINDEX, ERIC)
- “seat saving” OR “saving seats” AND (library OR classroom OR lecture hall) AND university
- “seat reservation” AND (library OR study space) AND university
- “territoriality” AND (library OR study spaces OR classroom) AND students
- “proxemics” AND (classroom OR lecture hall) AND seating
- “informal learning spaces” AND students AND “space use” OR “study space occupancy”
- “resource scarcity” AND “study spaces” AND university
- “public seating norms” AND university OR campus
- “classroom seating preferences” OR “seat choice” AND performance AND university
- “library seat occupancy” OR “desk occupancy” AND sensors AND university
- “norm enforcement” AND (library OR classroom) AND students

Multilingual queries (often yield rich case studies)
- Chinese: 大学生 图书馆 占座 现象, 图书馆 座位 预约 系统 研究, 高校 图书馆 学习 空间 使用
- Korean: 대학생 도서관 자리 맡기, 대학 도서관 좌석 예약 시스템, 학습 공간 이용
- Japanese: 大学 図書館 席 取り 行為, 学習スペース 利用
- Spanish: estudiantes universitarios reserva de asientos biblioteca aula, territorialidad espacio público universidad
- German: Sitzplatzreservierung Hochschule Bibliothek, Territorialität Lernräume Universität

Adjacent disciplines and venues likely to contain relevant empirical studies
- Library & Information Science and Higher Education: College & Research Libraries, The Journal of Academic Librarianship, portal: Libraries and the Academy, Higher Education Research & Development.
- Human-Computer Interaction / campus infrastructure: CHI, CSCW, UbiComp, Learning Spaces literature; studies on seat-reservation apps, occupancy sensors, and space usage analytics.
- Education psychology and classroom studies: Studies on seating preferences, seating location, and social grouping in lectures may touch on informal “saving seats” norms even if not named explicitly.

Conceptual frameworks from Sociology and Social Psychology to anchor analysis
- Erving Goffman: Behavior in Public Places; Relations in Public (micro-interactions, claims to space, civil inattention, norm breaches).
- Edward T. Hall: The Hidden Dimension (proxemics; personal territories in shared environments).
- Altman (and Edney, Stokols): Territoriality and crowding; place-claiming, markers, and norm enforcement in public/shared spaces.
- Commons and resource allocation: Norms in use of public/commons spaces, informal governance, moral economy of space (who can save seats, for how long, legitimacy of placeholders).
- Social norms and sanctions: Descriptive vs. injunctive norms around seat saving; peer enforcement and conflict.

Specific topical clusters likely to surface relevant papers
- Library seat reservation systems: evaluations of booking platforms, “no-shows,” fairness, and policy impacts.
- Study-space occupancy and sensor-based audits: papers measuring seat occupancy/desk hogging with cameras/sensors; interventions (e.g., time limits).
- Classroom seating behavior: group formations, friendship networks, and territorial clustering; seating choice effects on engagement and performance.
- Policy and signage studies: effectiveness of rules or campaigns addressing “seat hogging” in libraries.

Example query strings combining multiple angles
- (“library seat reservation” OR “study space booking” OR “seat booking system”) AND (university OR campus) AND (evaluation OR fairness OR policy)
- (“territorial behavior” OR “place claiming” OR “desk hogging”) AND (library OR study space) AND (students)
- (“classroom seating” OR “seat choice”) AND (norms OR networks OR territoriality) AND (lecture hall)

Data-driven and regional leads
- UK/US academic libraries often publish case studies on seat-reservation policies, occupancy analytics, and user behavior.
- East Asian universities (China, Korea) have articles and theses explicitly on 占座 (seat-saving) phenomena in libraries and study rooms.

Recommended databases and filters
- Google Scholar: start broad, then filter by “Since 2015,” and “Library & Information Science” or “Education.”
- Scopus/Web of Science: combine topic keywords with subject areas “Sociology,” “Education,” “Library Science,” “HCI.”
- ERIC: for classroom seating behavior and policy in higher education.
- JSTOR/SocINDEX: for sociological theory and public space behavior.
- ACM Digital Library/IEEE Xplore: for HCI analyses of seat-reservation systems and occupancy sensing.

Next steps I can take for you
- Rerun targeted searches focusing on specific contexts (library vs. classroom), languages, or regions.
- Compile an annotated bibliography with abstracts and methodological notes.
- Include theoretical framing tying empirical findings to sociological concepts (norms, territoriality, proxemics, commons governance).

Please tell me:
- Preferred context (library study spaces, lecture halls, or both),
- Language/region focus,
- Time window (e.g., since 2010),
- Whether you want only peer-reviewed journal articles or also conference papers and theses.

I’ll then refine and deliver a curated list of the most relevant papers with summaries and links.

- Moderate growth: Oracle and Accenture benefit from the cloud/AI wave—Oracle via DB/OCI/SaaS, Accenture via services-led transformation.

- Convergence themes: Cloud, data platforms, and AI are universal priorities. All six are embedding AI into offerings—either as platforms (Microsoft, Google, Oracle, IBM) or in process-centric applications/services (SAP, Accenture).

- Legacy modernization: database, ERP, and mainframe migrations to hybrid/cloud.
- Sustainability, reporting, and risk analytics embedded into enterprise processes.

Bottom line
- Microsoft and Google are best positioned for AI-scale monetization via cloud platforms and ubiquitous productivity integrations.
- Oracle’s strength remains in data and mission-critical enterprise workloads, with steady cloud/SaaS gains.
- SAP’s advantage is process depth and industry footprint; growth hinges on the pace of S/4HANA Cloud migration.
- IBM is focused on hybrid control and enterprise AI/quantum differentiation amid slower topline growth.
- Accenture translates these technology shifts into pragmatic enterprise outcomes, benefiting as the neutral prime integrator.

Here’s what I’ve done and how to complete everything in Blender:

What I applied via tools
- Sun orientation and tone: Set the “sun” rotation to 45° around Z (northeast) and warmed its color slightly for a more natural outdoor look.
- Bird creation attempts: I attempted to create “SkyBird” twice via the object tool, once with string-formatted coordinates and once with numeric coordinates. The API showed conflicting validation requirements, so I’m providing a robust Blender script below that will: 
  - Create “SkyBird” at [0, 50, 100] with size 1.5
  - Add a natural yellow material
  - Ensure a sky environment
  - Animate a natural, random flight pattern that automatically responds to the sun’s direction (interdependent behavior)

Blender setup script (paste into Blender’s Text Editor and Run Script)
import bpy
import math
from math import radians
from mathutils import Vector, Euler, noise

# 1) Ensure a sky environment (World -> Sky Texture), natural daylight feel
world = bpy.data.worlds.get("World")
if not world:
    world = bpy.data.worlds.new("World")
bpy.context.scene.world = world
world.use_nodes = True
wn = world.node_tree
nodes = wn.nodes
links = wn.links

bg = nodes.get("Background")
if not bg:
    bg = nodes.new(type="ShaderNodeBackground")
out = nodes.get("World Output")
if not out:
    out = nodes.new(type="ShaderNodeOutputWorld")

sky = nodes.get("Sky Texture")
if not sky:
    sky = nodes.new(type="ShaderNodeTexSky")
    sky.sky_type = 'HOSEK_WILKIE'
    sky.turbidity = 2.5
# Link sky -> background -> output
if not any(l.to_node == bg and l.from_node == sky for l in links):
    links.new(sky.outputs["Color"], bg.inputs["Color"])
if not any(l.to_node == out and l.from_node == bg for l in links):
    links.new(bg.outputs["Background"], out.inputs["Surface"])

# 2) Ensure there is a Sun light object oriented to northeast (45° around Z)
sun = bpy.data.objects.get("sun")
if not sun:
    # Create a Sun light if missing
    light_data = bpy.data.lights.new(name="sun_light", type='SUN')
    sun = bpy.data.objects.new(name="sun", object_data=light_data)
    bpy.context.scene.collection.objects.link(sun)
# Set rotation to face northeast (45° yaw about Z)
sun.rotation_euler = Euler((0.0, 0.0, radians(45.0)), 'XYZ')
# Slightly warm the sun’s color/intensity
if hasattr(sun.data, "color"):
    sun.data.color = (1.0, 0.94, 0.78)
    sun.data.energy = 5.0

# Optionally tie world sun rotation to the sun lamp yaw for coherence
try:
    sky.inputs["Sun Rotation"].default_value = sun.rotation_euler.z
except Exception:
    pass

# 3) Create the bird "SkyBird" at [0, 50, 100] with size 1.5 and natural yellow look
bird = bpy.data.objects.get("SkyBird")
if not bird:
    bpy.ops.mesh.primitive_uv_sphere_add(enter_editmode=False, location=(0.0, 50.0, 100.0))
    bird = bpy.context.active_object
    bird.name = "SkyBird"
# Uniform size 1.5
bird.scale = (1.5, 1.5, 1.5)

# Add to "SkyView" collection if it exists for scene organization
skyview_coll = bpy.data.collections.get("SkyView")
if skyview_coll and bird.name not in skyview_coll.objects:
    # Link if not already; ensure it’s not duplicated in master
    try:
        bpy.context.scene.collection.objects.unlink(bird)
    except Exception:
        pass
    skyview_coll.objects.link(bird)

# Create a natural yellow material
mat = bpy.data.materials.get("SkyBird_Yellow")
if not mat:
    mat = bpy.data.materials.new("SkyBird_Yellow")
    mat.use_nodes = True
    nt = mat.node_tree
    bsdf = nt.nodes.get("Principled BSDF")
    if bsdf:
        # Warm yellow
        bsdf.inputs["Base Color"].default_value = (1.0, 0.9, 0.1, 1.0)
        bsdf.inputs["Roughness"].default_value = 0.45
        bsdf.inputs["Specular"].default_value = 0.35
if mat and mat.name not in [m.name for m in bird.data.materials]:
    bird.data.materials.append(mat)

# 4) Natural random flight pattern interdependent with sun direction
base = Vector((0.0, 50.0, 100.0))

def get_sun_dir():
    s = bpy.data.objects.get("sun")
    if not s:
        # Default NE if missing
        return Vector((1.0, 1.0, 0.0)).normalized()
    yaw = s.rotation_euler.z
    # Direction in XY plane given yaw (Z rotation)
    return Vector((math.cos(yaw), math.sin(yaw), 0.0)).normalized()

def skybird_flight(scene):
    b = bpy.data.objects.get("SkyBird")
    if not b:
        return
    f = scene.frame_current / 24.0  # seconds if 24 fps
    sdir = get_sun_dir()
    # Orthogonal lateral direction within the sky plane
    orth = Vector((-sdir.y, sdir.x, 0.0))

    # Smooth pseudo-random variations using Blender's noise
    n_forward = noise.noise(Vector((f * 0.35, 0.0, 0.0)))   # forward drift
    n_lateral = noise.noise(Vector((0.0, f * 0.25, 1.0)))   # side-to-side
    n_vertical = noise.noise(Vector((0.0, 1.0, f * 0.40)))  # altitude

    # Compose position with sun-dependent forward bias
    pos = base \
          + sdir * (50.0 * (0.4 + 0.6 * n_forward)) \
          + orth * (30.0 * n_lateral) \
          + Vector((0.0, 0.0, 1.0)) * (15.0 * n_vertical)

    b.location = pos

    # Orient bird to its instantaneous flight vector
    forward = (sdir * (0.7 + 0.3 * n_forward) + orth * (0.6 * n_lateral) + Vector((0,0,1)) * (0.2 * n_vertical)).normalized()
    # Compute yaw and pitch from forward vector
    horiz = Vector((forward.x, forward.y, 0.0))
    yaw = math.atan2(horiz.y, horiz.x) if horiz.length > 1e-6 else 0.0
    pitch = math.atan2(forward.z, max(horiz.length, 1e-6))
    b.rotation_euler = Euler((pitch, 0.0, yaw), 'XYZ')

# Remove prior copies of the handler to avoid duplicates
for h in list(bpy.app.handlers.frame_change_pre):
    if getattr(h, "__name__", "") == "skybird_flight":
        bpy.app.handlers.frame_change_pre.remove(h)
bpy.app.handlers.frame_change_pre.append(skybird_flight)

# Set a reasonable frame range for preview
scene = bpy.context.scene
if scene.frame_end < 600:
    scene.frame_end = 600

print("SkyView enhanced: sun oriented NE, SkyBird created and flying with sun-coupled natural dynamics.")

How to use
- Run the script above in Blender. Press Play on the timeline to see SkyBird fly across SkyView.
- To adjust the sun direction interactively, rotate the “sun” object around Z; SkyBird’s path will immediately adapt.
- To stop the flight handler later, run:
  import bpy
  for h in list(bpy.app.handlers.frame_change_pre):
      if getattr(h, "__name__", "") == "skybird_flight":
          bpy.app.handlers.frame_change_pre.remove(h)

Notes
- Sun was rotated 45° to the right (northeast) as requested.
- SkyBird is positioned at [0, 50, 100], size 1.5, with a natural yellow material.
- The flight is random but biased by the sun’s current direction, ensuring interdependence with lighting.
- If you already have a specific “SkyView” collection, the bird is linked there for clean organization. If not, it remains in the main collection.

- Objective: Provide separate literature sets on (1) hereditary probabilities of genetic diseases and (2) heritability of mental disorders, then explore variant–health associations for EFO_0000270.
- Plan:
  1) Use search_pubmed for “genetic diseases heritability/recurrence risk/probability” (maxResults=5).
  2) Use search_pubmed for “mental disorders heritability/family recurrence/twin studies” (maxResults=5).
  3) Use get_trait_associations for EFO_0000270 to summarize GWAS associations and interpret health status links.
- Tools and parameters:
  - search_pubmed(query="genetic diseases heritability recurrence risk probability", maxResults=5)
  - search_pubmed(query="mental disorders heritability family recurrence risk twin studies", maxResults=5)
  - get_trait_associations(efoId="EFO_0000270")

Here are the results and a concise synthesis.

Literature: hereditary probabilities of genetic diseases (selected highlights)
- Hereditary Probabilities of Genetic Diseases: A Comprehensive Review (Genetic Epidemiology, 2019)
  - Scope: Reviews transmission patterns, penetrance, recurrence risks, and estimation methods across Mendelian conditions.
  - Use: Foundation for calculating carrier risks, recurrence risk by inheritance type (AD/AR/X-linked), and counseling frameworks.
- Huntington's Disease: Genetic Mechanisms and Therapeutic Approaches (Nature Genetics, 2023)
  - Scope: Mechanistic review of CAG repeat expansion, inheritance risk, and emerging gene therapies.
  - Use: Concrete case study of autosomal dominant inheritance with age-dependent penetrance and genetic testing implications.
- Note: Two GVHD-focused items surfaced in search results (EFO_0000305), which are not directly about hereditary probabilities in the general population; they were excluded from the highlights above.

Literature: heritability of mental disorders (selected highlights)
- Genetic Risk Factors for Mental Disorders: Insights from GWAS (Psychiatric Genetics, 2022)
  - Scope: Synthesizes large-scale GWAS findings across major psychiatric conditions; discusses polygenicity, common vs rare variants, and genetic correlations.
  - Use: Context for interpreting SNP-heritability, family recurrence risk, and the role of polygenic risk scores (PRS) in mental health.
- Note: The same two GVHD items appeared in this search as well and are not relevant to psychiatric heritability, so they are omitted here.

GWAS associations for EFO_0000270 (trait: cystic fibrosis) and health status
- Reported association (from get_trait_associations):
  - Variant: rs113993960
  - Gene: CFTR
  - Effect: beta = -2.5 on FEV1 % predicted (a lung function measure tied to health status)
  - p-value: 1.20e-20
  - Study: “CFTR variants and lung function decline in cystic fibrosis” (European ancestry)
  - Publication: PMID 22085960 (Am J Respir Crit Care Med, 2011)
- Interpretation:
  - The association links specific CFTR genetic variation with reduced lung function (lower FEV1 % predicted), a clinically meaningful health-status endpoint in CF.
  - Very strong statistical significance suggests a robust relationship in the studied population; generalizability to non-European ancestries should be validated.
  - Clinically, such genotype–phenotype links can inform prognosis, stratify patients by expected lung function decline, and support personalized interventions.

Practical next steps (optional)
- For genetic diseases:
  - Search terms to refine: “recurrence risk AND Mendelian,” “penetrance estimation,” “segregation analysis,” “carrier probability Bayesian,” “X-linked recurrence risk counseling.”
- For mental disorders:
  - Search terms to refine: “twin study heritability schizophrenia/bipolar/ADHD,” “SNP-heritability meta-analysis,” “family recurrence risk depression,” “polygenic risk score validation.”
- For EFO_0000270:
  - Extend to modifier genes and additional health outcomes: “cystic fibrosis modifier genes GWAS,” “FEV1 decline CF longitudinal GWAS,” “extra-pulmonary outcomes CFTR genotype.”

If you’d like, I can pull more targeted PubMed results (e.g., twin/family studies per specific disorder), or expand GWAS associations for cystic fibrosis (additional variants, ancestries, and phenotypes).

  - Pipedrive: deals, organizations, persons, activities
    - Incremental field: update_time/add_time; use since parameter and pagination

- Incremental strategy and idempotency
  - Maintain high-watermarks per entity in a control table (BigQuery) or Firestore:
    - control.ingestion_state: source, entity, last_successful_cursor, run_id, watermark_ts
  - Fetch incrementals with updated_since >= watermark; deduplicate by natural keys:
    - invoice_id, payment_id, deal_id, org_id, person_id, activity_id
  - Upserts in staging and core using MERGE into BigQuery (idempotent runs)

- Data landing and schema handling
  - Raw ingestion as newline-delimited JSON with source metadata:
    - _source, _ingested_at_utc, _version, _cursor, _run_id
  - Flexible schemas to absorb additive columns (schema drift); treat unknowns as JSON columns to be flattened in staging

- Transformations (dbt)
  - Staging models (stg_*): flatten raw JSON, cast types, standardize timestamps to UTC, add _ingested_at
  - Core models:
    - Dimensions: dim_customer (Zoho), dim_organization (Pipedrive), dim_person (Pipedrive) with SCD Type 2 for slowly changing attributes
    - Facts: fact_invoices, fact_payments, fact_deals, fact_activities
    - Cross-system integration:
      - Matching keys via email, organization name, external_id mapping table (map_customer_org), fuzzy matching fallback (e.g., normalized company name + domain)
      - Bridge table: bridge_customer_org_person linking Zoho customers to Pipedrive orgs/persons
    - Integrated revenue model: fact_revenue with invoice/payment details linked to deals when available
  - Marts:
    - business_data_summary: monthly aggregates with total_revenue, total_expenses, net_profit
    - Optional: pipeline_health, dq_results, sales_funnel_summary

- Data quality checks
  - Completeness: required fields non-null (invoice_id, deal_id, amounts, dates)
  - Uniqueness: no duplicate IDs per source/day
  - Referential integrity: payments → invoices; deals → org/person
  - Range checks: amounts >= 0; dates within plausible bounds
  - DQ logging table and alerting on threshold breaches

- Privacy and compliance
  - Minimize PII: mask emails/phone in marts; restrict access via dataset-level IAM
  - Honor GDPR/CCPA: maintain deletion requests log; propagate deletes to downstream tables

- Observability and reliability
  - Structured logs (Cloud Logging); metrics (Cloud Monitoring): success/failure counts, latency, record volumes
  - Alerts: ingestion failures, DQ failures, API throttling/backoff events
  - Retries: exponential backoff with jitter; DLQ Pub/Sub for malformed records
  - Replay: DLQ replay jobs and archived raw reprocess capability

- Cost optimization
  - BigQuery partitioning and clustering:
    - Partition facts by event/invoice_date; cluster by customer_id, deal_id
  - Query pruning in marts; materialized views for common aggregates
  - Storage lifecycle on GCS archived data

- Security and IAM
  - Service accounts:
    - extractor-sa: Secret Manager accessor, GCS writer, Pub/Sub publisher
    - transform-sa: BigQuery data editor on staging/core/marts, GCS reader
  - Least privilege per dataset and bucket; secrets in Secret Manager (Zoho, Pipedrive tokens), auto-refresh OAuth where applicable

- Backfill support
  - Parameterized backfill windows (start_date, end_date)
  - Throttle to respect API rate limits; chunked historical loads

- Concrete BigQuery layout (examples)
  - raw: raw_zoho_invoices, raw_zoho_payments, raw_zoho_customers, raw_pipedrive_deals, raw_pipedrive_organizations, raw_pipedrive_persons, raw_pipedrive_activities
  - staging: stg_zoho_invoices, stg_zoho_payments, stg_zoho_customers, stg_pipedrive_deals, stg_pipedrive_orgs, stg_pipedrive_persons, stg_pipedrive_activities
  - core: dim_customer, dim_organization, dim_person, fact_invoices, fact_payments, fact_deals, bridge_customer_org_person, fact_revenue
  - marts: business_data_summary, sales_mart tables

- Example business_data_summary logic (dbt model)
  - Aggregate by invoice/payment posted date (UTC), join expenses if tracked, compute monthly totals:
    - total_revenue: sum of paid invoice amounts
    - total_expenses: sum of expense entries (if provided from Zoho or separate source)
    - net_profit: revenue − expenses

Next steps to implement
1) Provision GCP resources: GCS buckets (raw/archive), BigQuery datasets (raw, staging, core, marts), Pub/Sub topics, Secret Manager entries for Zoho/Pipedrive credentials.
2) Build extractors (Cloud Run/Functions) with incremental cursors and pagination; write raw NDJSON to GCS; publish completion message to Pub/Sub.
3) Orchestrate with Dataflow/Composer to load raw → staging; run dbt for staging/core/marts.
4) Implement control tables for high-watermarks and DQ results; set up Monitoring alerts.
5) Validate end-to-end with a limited backfill; then enable daily schedule at 02:00 UTC.

If you want, I can provide starter dbt model templates and a minimal schema for the mapping table to link Zoho customers to Pipedrive organizations/persons.

content.content:
[{"type": "text", "text": "Task Plan for: Zoho Invoice + Pipedrive to BigQuery Data Pipeline
Scope: Build an automated ELT pipeline that extracts business data from Zoho Invoice (invoices, payments, customers) and Pipedrive (deals, organizations, persons, activities), lands raw JSON in Cloud Storage, normalizes/cleanses into a canonical revenue and sales model, integrates cross-system keys, and loads curated tables to BigQuery datasets: raw, staging, core, and marts (including the business_data_summary table). Include incremental loading, deduplication, data quality checks, and backfill support.
Schedule (cron): 0 2 * * *
Constraints:
  - Respect Zoho and Pipedrive API rate limits and pagination.
  - Use OAuth2/API tokens stored in Secret Manager; automate token refresh.
  - Handle schema drift (additive columns) with flexible ingestion schemas.
  - Ensure idempotent incremental loads using updated_since cursors and high-watermarks.
  - Implement retries with exponential backoff and network error handling.
  - Apply data quality checks (completeness, duplicates, referential integrity).
  - Mask or exclude PII to meet compliance requirements; manage GDPR/CCPA requests.
  - Normalize timezones to UTC and track source ingestion timestamps.
  - Optimize BigQuery cost via partitioning, clustering, and query pruning.
  - Provide observability: structured logs, metrics, and alerting (error rates, latency).
  - Enforce least-privilege IAM roles for service accounts and datasets.
  - Use a dead-letter queue for malformed records and failed transformations.
  - Version transformations (dbt) and maintain CI/CD for pipeline code.
Dependencies:
  - Zoho Invoice API: Invoices, Payments, Customers endpoints
  - Pipedrive API: Deals, Activities, Organizations, Persons endpoints
  - Google Cloud Scheduler for cron triggering
  - Google Cloud Run or Cloud Functions for extract workers
  - Google Pub/Sub for event-driven orchestration
  - Google Cloud Storage (GCS) raw landing and archived buckets
  - Google Dataflow (Apache Beam) or Cloud Composer (Airflow) for workflow orchestration
  - dbt for SQL-based transformations in BigQuery
  - Google BigQuery datasets: raw, staging, core, marts
  - BigQuery table: business_data_summary (mart)
  - Google Secret Manager for credentials
  - Google Cloud Monitoring and Logging for observability
  - Google Cloud Build/GitHub Actions for CI/CD
  - IAM service accounts and roles for secure access

Breakdown:
Step 1: Define data sources and confirm data extraction readiness (Clarify any assumptions from constraints.)
Step 2: Perform data cleaning and transformation (Ensure data quality, enforce privacy constraints.)
Step 3: Integrate datasets as per scope requirements (Consider dependencies for upstream/downstream tasks.)
Step 4: Load final dataset to target destination (Match loading schedule to given cadence.)
", "annotations": null}]

Vaccination and preventive guidance for an 18-year-old female (not pregnant):
- Core vaccines:
  - Influenza: annually
  - COVID-19: stay up to date per current guidelines
  - Tdap once, then Td booster every 10 years
  - HPV: complete series if not finished (recommended up to age 26)
  - Meningococcal ACWY: recommended if living in dorms/communal housing; MenB may be considered based on risk/policy

  - Hepatitis B: ensure completed series; Hepatitis A considered based on risk/travel

  - Blood pressure: every 1–2 years
  - Lipids: every 4–6 years (earlier/more often if risk factors)

  - STIs: chlamydia/gonorrhea annually if sexually active and under 25; HIV at least once
  - Cervical cancer (Pap smear): begins at age 21, then every 3 years to 29 if normal
- Healthy habits:
  - Diet: balanced meals with fruits, vegetables, whole grains, lean protein, healthy fats
  - Activity: ≥150 minutes/week moderate exercise + 2 days/week strength training
  - Substance use: avoid smoking/vaping; alcohol is illegal at 18—avoid use
  - Sleep: 7–9 hours/night
  - Sun safety: SPF 30+, protective clothing
  - Mental health: stress management, social support; seek care if persistent low mood/anxiety

- Build a balanced plate:
  - Half plate vegetables/fruits (aim color variety)
  - Quarter plate whole grains (e.g., oats, brown rice, whole-wheat pasta)
  - Quarter plate lean protein (beans, lentils, yogurt, eggs, poultry, fish)
  - Add healthy fats (nuts, seeds, olive oil) in moderation
- Fiber targets: 25–30 g/day; emphasize oats, legumes, vegetables, fruits, seeds
- Protein targets: about 0.8–1.2 g/kg body weight/day depending on activity
- Limit added sugars: ideally <25 g/day; watch beverages and snacks
- Sodium: aim <2,300 mg/day; choose minimally processed foods
- Hydration: roughly 2–2.5 liters/day (more with activity/heat)
- Label savvy: check serving size, added sugar, sodium, and percent daily values
- Smart snack ideas:
  - Apple + peanut butter; Banana + Greek yogurt; Carrot sticks + hummus; Oats with berries and chia
- Practical meal planning:
  - Prep oats overnight; batch-roast vegetables; keep frozen veggies/fruit on hand; pack balanced snacks

Requirements:
1) Deterministic synthetic dataset:
   - Use numpy with a fixed random seed (e.g., 42) to ensure reproducibility.
   - For each year in [2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023] and each day in [1..15], generate features and targets:
     * Features X: [day_of_month, year]
     * Targets y: [avg_temp_celsius, precip_probability]

     * base_temp(day) = 6.0 + (day - 1) * 0.25  # ~6°C on Mar 1 trending to ~9.5°C on Mar 15 for 2019
     * annual_trend(year) = 0.1 * (year - 2019)
     * noise ~ Normal(0, 0.3)
     * avg_temp = base_temp(day) + annual_trend(year) + noise
   - Construct precip_probability (as a fraction 0..1) with mild day variation and noise:
     * base_precip(day) = 0.38 + (day - 1) * 0.005  # ~38% on Mar 1 to ~45% on Mar 15
     * noise ~ Normal(0, 0.03)
     * precip = clip(base_precip(day) + noise, 0, 1)

2) Model:

Thought:
- The user wants an analysis of current marketing strategies based on products and sales data and five optimization suggestions.
- To ground the analysis, I will first retrieve the available schemas and tables in the default e-commerce database to understand what data sources are present.
- Tool to use: E_commerce_analyst_MCP_get_schemas with empty filter and default database.
- After retrieving schemas, I will infer typical current strategies observable from these data structures and provide five concrete optimization suggestions, each tied to specific metrics and implementation steps using the available tables.

Analysis of current marketing strategies (based on the available data structures):
- Product reviews and UGC are likely leveraged: The presence of product_reviews suggests reliance on social proof to drive conversion and SEO for product pages.
- Discount-led promotions and seasonal pushes: sales_orders and sales_transactions typically capture promo codes and markdowns, indicating periodic price promotions and event-based marketing.
- Retention via loyalty: customer_loyalty indicates a points/tier program, suggesting strategies around repeat purchases and member-exclusive offers.
- Category-led merchandising: product_categories implies category-specific marketing (e.g., bestsellers, new arrivals, curated collections).
- Reactive inventory marketing: stock_levels indicates potential alignment of marketing with availability; however, marketing may not fully optimize around overstock/stockout risk.
- Returns impact on messaging: sales_returns likely show categories/SKUs with higher return rates that require better pre-purchase information (sizing, materials, compatibility).

Five optimization suggestions, with actions and metrics:
1) Strengthen the review flywheel on low-review SKUs
   - What to do: Automate post-purchase email/SMS for review requests, add Q&A on product pages, highlight review snippets in ads. Target SKUs with <10 reviews or <4.2 average rating.
   - Where in data: product_reviews (counts, averages) mapped to product_list and product_categories; correlate with sales_orders per SKU.
   - KPI: Conversion rate lift on targeted SKUs; average rating and review volume; organic traffic to product pages.

2) Shift from blanket discounts to margin-aware, category-specific promo optimization
   - What to do: Identify categories with healthy margins and low return rates for promos; avoid deep discounts on high-return SKUs. Test targeted markdowns vs sitewide sales.
   - Where in data: sales_transactions (promo codes, discount amounts), sales_returns (return rates by SKU/category), product_list (cost/margin if available; otherwise infer via price bands).
   - KPI: Gross margin after discounts, return rate delta, ROAS per category/promo, net contribution per order.

3) Lifecycle retention automation using RFM segmentation
   - What to do: Classify customers into segments (high-value, at-risk, new, lapsed) using Recency, Frequency, Monetary from sales_orders; tailor replenishment, cross-sell, and win-back flows; use customer_loyalty tiers for differentiated benefits.
   - Where in data: sales_orders (order dates, totals by customer), customer_profiles, customer_loyalty (tier/points).
   - KPI: Repeat purchase rate, time-to-next-order, AOV per segment, unsubscribe rate.

4) Cross-sell and bundling based on basket affinity
   - What to do: Analyze co-purchase patterns to create bundles and in-cart recommendations; feature complementary items on product pages; prioritize cross-category bundles where returns are low.
   - Where in data: sales_orders (line items if available; otherwise order-level SKU lists), product_categories to group complements.
   - KPI: AOV lift, attach rate of recommended items, bundle sell-through, return rate on bundles vs singles.

5) Inventory-aware marketing and stockout risk mitigation
   - What to do: Promote overstocked items with targeted ads; pause campaigns for low-stock SKUs; add “limited stock” messaging to drive urgency; expand preorders/back-in-stock notifications.
   - Where in data: stock_levels (current quantity, aging stock), sales_orders (sell-through velocity), warehouse_locations (fulfillment constraints).
   - KPI: Sell-through of aging stock, stockout rate on promoted SKUs, ad waste reduction (impressions on low/zero stock), back-in-stock subscription growth.

Quick validation metrics to run:
- Review-conversion relationship: Aggregate product_reviews by SKU and compare review volume/average rating against sales velocity from sales_orders.
- Promo ROI and returns: Compare orders with vs. without promo codes in sales_transactions; measure margin and return rates via sales_returns by category.
- RFM segmentation: Compute recency (days since last order), frequency (orders per period), monetary (LTV) from sales_orders; map to customer_loyalty tiers.
- Cross-sell opportunities: Identify top co-occurring SKU pairs/triples within sales_orders to prioritize bundles and recommendations.
- Inventory alignment: Identify SKUs with high stock_levels but low recent sell-through; flag SKUs with frequent stockouts to adjust ad delivery and messaging.

If you’d like, I can outline sample queries for each metric or help prioritize these initiatives based on your current business goals (growth vs. profitability vs. retention).

chat_message.content:
Thought:
- You want to build a UE5 battle royale and asked for two phases: 1) generate 10 combat-suitable 3D environment assets for scene construction; 2) combine these environments to design the battle mechanisms and gameplay via strategic analysis.
- Plan:
  1) Use generate_3d_assets to produce 10 GLB assets tailored to “battle royal style.”
  2) Use strategy_guide to scaffold the strategic analysis, then augment with concrete UE5 implementation details, metrics, and actionable ranges.
- Tool parameters:
  - generate_3d_assets(player_bio="battle royal style", num_assets="10")
  - strategy_guide(situation="UE5 battle royale: 4x4 km map, ~100 players, solo/squad modes; provide environment utilization, player flow, loot, engagement balance, zone pacing, spawn/drop, vehicles/traversal, events, respawn, technical optimization, anti-camping, matchmaking, with actionable recommendations and target ranges")

Here are your generated assets and a complete, practical guide to assemble them in UE5 and design the battle royale systems.

Phase 1: Generated 3D environment assets (GLB)
Use these as modular kits to build biomes and POIs. Each entry provides the prompt and GLB base64 payload.
1) Open Field Battleground Kit A
   - Prompt: Generate a generic open field battleground for battle royal style
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_FIELD_BASE64>
2) Small Urban Combat Zone Kit A
   - Prompt: Create a small urban combat zone adapted to battle royal style style
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_URBAN_BASE64>
3) Open Field Battleground Kit B
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_FIELD_BASE64>
4) Small Urban Combat Zone Kit B
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_URBAN_BASE64>
5) Open Field Battleground Kit C
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_FIELD_BASE64>
6) Small Urban Combat Zone Kit C
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_URBAN_BASE64>
7) Open Field Battleground Kit D
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_FIELD_BASE64>
8) Small Urban Combat Zone Kit D
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_URBAN_BASE64>
9) Open Field Battleground Kit E
   - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_FIELD_BASE64>
10) Small Urban Combat Zone Kit E
    - GLB: <GLB_FILE_DATA_GENERIC_URBAN_BASE64>

How to import and prep assets in UE5
- Enable Plugins: glTF Importer (Editor > Plugins), Nanite and Lumen (Project Settings).
- Import GLB: Content Browser > Import > select .glb. Check Generate Materials, Import Normals/Tangents, Import Scale = 1.0 (verify units; glTF is meters).
- Static Mesh Prep:
  - Open each mesh in Static Mesh Editor: enable Nanite, build collision (Simple + Complex as Simple where needed), set LODs (Nanite mostly obviates LODs).
  - Create Master Materials (Landscape, Foliage, Urban) and per-asset Material Instances. Use packed textures (ORM) if available.
  - Generate HLODs for clustered urban sets; use Hierarchical Instanced Static Mesh for repeated props (cover, walls, foliage).
- Blueprinting:
  - Wrap each kit into a Blueprint Actor (BP_FieldKit_X, BP_UrbanKit_X) with exposed parameters (rotation, scale, seed) to quickly instance variations.
  - Add NavMeshBoundsVolume in each kit BP if you’ll place them as level instances for AI/bots.

Phase 2: Level assembly in UE5
- World size: 4x4 km.
- Landscape:
  - Create a 4033×4033 Landscape for good tessellation; sculpt macro features (ridges, valleys, riverbeds).
  - Use Landscape Layers: soil, grass, rock; paint biomes.
- World Partition:
  - Enable World Partition and Data Layers. Set Cell Size around 250–500 m for efficient streaming.
  - Organize sub-levels by biome and POI: DataLayer_Field, DataLayer_Urban, DataLayer_Roads, DataLayer_Foliage, DataLayer_Loot, DataLayer_Vehicles.
- Level Instances:
  - Drop 6–8 POIs built from urban kits (town squares, warehouse yards, market alleys).
  - Fill between POIs with field kits configured as micro-terrain (gentle hills, hedgerows, scattered rocks).
- Cover ratio targets:
  - Open fields: 20–25% cover density (low cover, long sightlines).
  - Transitional outskirts: 25–30% cover.
  - Urban POIs: 30–35% cover (short sightlines, multiple flanking lanes).
- Sightline design:
  - Open areas: typical sightline 80–120 m; ensure intermittent soft cover.
  - Urban: sightlines 20–60 m; avoid >150 m straight kill corridors.
  - Limit high sniper perches so any perch has at least 2 flanking approaches and 1 counter-perch within 100 m.

Player flow and POI planning
- POIs: 8–12 total; 3 hot (high loot, high traffic), 4–6 medium, 2–3 low-risk outskirts.
- Spacing: 600–900 m between major POIs; minor compounds every 250–400 m.
- Roads and rotations:
  - Connect POIs with 2–3 paved routes and 2–3 dirt paths; embed soft cover nodes every 50–75 m (cars, crates, trees).
  - Add vantage nodes overlooking roads every 300–400 m for ambush risk.
- Player density per POI (for 100 players):
  - Hot: 12–20 players each.
  - Medium: 6–12 players each.
  - Low: 2–6 players each.

Drop and spawn logic
- Drop vehicle path:
  - 1–2 drop routes per match, varying angle and offset; speed ~200–250 km/h; jump altitude ~800 m.
  - Travel time across map ~45–60 seconds.
- Solo/squad:
  - Solo drop enabled anytime; squads spawn close within 50 m radius after jump.
- Safe initial spread:
  - Add two minor POIs under the flight path at 20–30 seconds to prevent overstacking at the first hot drop.

Loot distribution and tiers
- Loot tiers: Common, Uncommon, Rare, Epic, Legendary.
- Baseline weights in hot/medium/low areas:
  - Hot: Common 45%, Uncommon 30%, Rare 15%, Epic 7%, Legendary 3%.
  - Medium: Common 55%, Uncommon 25%, Rare 12%, Epic 6%, Legendary 2%.
  - Low: Common 65%, Uncommon 22%, Rare 9%, Epic 3%, Legendary 1%.
- Containers:
  - Floor loot 50–60%, containers/crates 35–45%, rare drops 3–5%.
- Dynamic loot scaler:
  - As circle shrinks, increase Epic/Legendary chance by +1–2% in next ring to compensate risk.
- Ammo/Healing:
  - Target 2–3 magazines per weapon found; healing abundance light early, ramp midgame.

Combat balance targets
- TTK targets: 0.4–0.8 seconds for mid-range rifles; SMGs shorter in urban; DMRs longer range, 2–3 shot down with headshots.
- Recoil and spread tuned so effective range matches sightlines: SMG 0–30 m; AR 20–120 m; DMR 60–200 m; Sniper 100–300 m (limited ammo).
- Destructible cover: selectively destructible (wood/softer props) to break entrenched positions without erasing all cover.

Circle shrink pacing and rules
- Phases (100 players):
  - Phase 0 (pre-drop): 0:00–0:30.
  - Phase 1: Start at 2:00, shrink time 1:30, rest 1:00.
  - Phase 2: Start 5:00, shrink 1:45, rest 1:15.
  - Phase 3: Start 8:00, shrink 2:00, rest 1:30.
  - Phase 4: Start 11:30, shrink 2:15, rest 1:45.
  - Phase 5: Start 15:30, shrink 2:30, rest 2:00.
  - Final closure: controlled oscillation or slow pinch over 90–120 seconds.
- Damage per tick ramps per phase; keep outside survival possible for 10–20 seconds early, <5 seconds late.
- Circle randomization: 20–30% bias away from previously centered hotspots to vary endings.

Traversal and vehicles
- Vehicle count: 12–20 total; 6–8 near roads, 4–6 near outskirts; fuel as limiting resource.
- Risk/Noise: vehicles loud, visible; higher speed on roads, lower off-road; soft cover nodes near road exits to avoid instant farm.

Events and pacing
- Airdrops: 2–4 per match; beacon color changes by tier; parachute landing near center or curve toward player density.
- Mini-objectives: recon towers reveal next circle; cash bounties; timed crates requiring lockpicks; all generate temporary hotspots.
- Weather/time: optional light fog or dusk to change sightlines; avoid heavy fog unless short match variant.

Respawn options (pick one)
- Classic BR: no respawn.
- Token-based: collect 1–2 tokens + visit beacon to respawn a teammate; re-entry altitude 400 m, invulnerability 3 seconds on landing.
- Duel/Gulag variant: opt-in after first death until Phase 3.

Anti-camping mechanics
- Rotating recon pings at high-value POIs; stationary players for >45 seconds in hot zones briefly light up on UAV sweeps.
- Field-of-view and audio occlusion balanced to reward movement and awareness; suppress infinite healing loops with diminishing returns.
- Bounty system: occasionally mark top-killer for rewards; compels movement.
- Supply zones deplete over time to push rotations.

Fair matchmaking
- Input-based queues (KBM vs controller) with optional mixed; low-latency region selection.
- Lightweight MMR using last 10 matches: placements, kills, damage/min; squads use average or highest member MMR plus role balancing.
- Protect fresh accounts with soft SBMM floors and generous loot in early lobbies.

Technical optimization for UE5
- World Partition + Streaming Sources: attach sources to player and vehicles.
- Nanite meshes: all static environment; disable on thin foliage, use WPO wind sparingly.
- Lumen: enable with hardware ray tracing optional; cap emissive, control bounce with reflection captures in interiors.
- HLODs: build for urban clusters; test streaming thresholds to avoid pop-in.
- Replication:
  - Server-authoritative movement; client-side prediction and reconciliation.
  - Set Net Cull Distance for non-critical actors; dormancy for static props; prioritize players and projectiles.
  - NetUpdateFrequency: players 30–45; minor actors 10–20; use relevancy filters by circle.
- Performance targets: 60 fps on mid-tier GPUs; profiling with Unreal Insights; optimize Blueprints into C++ for net-critical systems.
- Security: server validation for damage, inventory, movement; anti-teleport and hit-scan sanity checks.

System implementation outline (UE5)
- Circle Manager: Blueprint or C++ actor with DataAsset for phases; exposes events to UI and EQS for airdrop targeting.
- Loot Spawner:
  - DataAssets per POI for loot tables and weights; random seed per match; pre-warm only for relevant streaming cells.
- Drop Vehicle:
  - Spline-based actor for path; spawn-time RNG to vary start/end; handles jump input and squad clustering.
- Vehicles:
  - Physical wheels or chaos vehicles; fuel as attribute; replication optimized with lower tick when far.
- Gameplay Ability System (GAS):
  - Use GAS for stamina, healing, buffs; easy to network and balance.
- Telemetry:
  - Track landing density, time-to-first-fight, survival time, damage sources; tune cover ratios and loot weights accordingly.

Using the assets as biomes and level instances
- Open Field Kits: place as macro tiles between POIs; rotate/scale to vary; add hedgerows, rock clusters, shallow trenches for movement safety.
- Urban Kits: compose into 3–5 building blocks per POI (market courtyard, alley network, warehouse yard). Ensure 2–3 ingress/egress routes per POI.
- Convert each kit to Level Instance; use Data Layers to toggle variations per match if desired (seasonal rotations).

Next steps and milestones
1) Import and prep the 10 GLB kits; create Blueprints and Material Instances; verify Nanite, collision.
2) Sculpt 4x4 km Landscape; lay out POIs using Urban kits; fill with Field kits; set cover and sightline targets.
3) Implement Circle Manager, Drop Vehicle, Loot Spawner, Vehicles; wire events (airdrops, recon towers).
4) Playtest with 40–60 bots plus 10–20 players; record metrics; tune loot weights, cover density, and circle pacing.
5) Optimize replication and streaming; finalize matchmaking rules; ship alpha.

If you want, I can turn each kit into a UE5-ready placement blueprint template with exposed parameters, or provide sample DataAsset templates for loot tables and circle phase configs.

- Objective: Build a reproducible pipeline to 1) retrieve prioritized targets for disease EFO_0000305 (Breast Cancer), 2) obtain detailed biological/druggability info for candidate targets, 3) calculate ADME/RO5/QED for BRCA1 candidate compound(s) from SMILES, and 4) integrate results into a drug design strategy aimed at selective enzyme/receptor targeting with improved efficacy and reduced toxicity.

Here are your results and a practical integration plan:

1) Prioritized disease-associated targets for EFO_0000305 (Breast Cancer)
- Identified targets:
  - ENSG00000012048 (BRCA1): tumor suppressor, DNA double-strand break repair via homologous recombination; high expression in breast/ovary; druggability score 0.85; modalities: small molecule and antibody; pathway-relevant known drugs: PARP inhibitors (e.g., Olaparib, Rucaparib); candidate SMILES: O=C(NC1=CC=CC=C1)C2=NC=NC=N2 (BRCA_path_mock2).
  - ENSG00000139618 (BRCA2): tumor suppressor, HR repair; druggability score 0.87; modalities: small molecule and antibody; known drugs: Olaparib, Rucaparib, Talazoparib; candidate SMILES: COC1=CC=CC=C1C(=O)N2C=NC3=CC=CC=C23 (BRCA_path_mock1).
  - ENSG00000141510 (TP53): transcription factor, “guardian of the genome”; druggability score 0.40; generally challenging for direct small-molecule modulation; listed mock candidate SMILES.
  - ENSG00000121879 (ERBB2/HER2): receptor tyrosine kinase frequently amplified in breast cancer; druggability score 0.92; modalities: small molecule and antibody; known drugs: Trastuzumab, Lapatinib, Pertuzumab; candidate SMILES: HER2_tki_mock1/HER2_tki_mock2.

Prioritization guidance:
- If the tumor is HER2-positive: ERBB2 is the top target (score 0.92), with strong precedent for selective inhibition via monoclonal antibodies or TKIs.
- If BRCA1/2 is mutated/deficient: prioritize synthetic lethality via PARP1/2 (linking BRCA1/2 biology to PARP inhibition). BRCA2 (0.87) and BRCA1 (0.85) both support this mechanism.
- TP53 has low direct druggability; favor pathway reactivation/indirect strategies (e.g., MDM2 inhibitors) rather than primary targeting.

2) Detailed biological and druggability insights (high-level implications)
- BRCA1/BRCA2: Loss-of-function sensitizes cells to PARP inhibition; therapeutic window arises from synthetic lethality. Important to optimize PARP selectivity and minimize off-target kinases/enzymes to reduce hematologic toxicity and GI adverse events. Consider combination strategies (ATR/Chk1 inhibitors) with careful DLT management.
- ERBB2 (HER2): A receptor tyrosine kinase; selectivity over EGFR and other ERBB family members reduces dermatologic and GI toxicity. Antibody-drug conjugates provide enhanced tumor selectivity via HER2 overexpression with payload choices tuned for bystander effect and systemic toxicity.
- TP53: Direct small-molecule druggability is limited; focus on restoring p53 function via MDM2/MDMX modulation or exploiting vulnerabilities created by p53 loss (e.g., cell cycle checkpoints).

3) ADME/Rule-of-Five/QED for BRCA1 candidate SMILES
- Candidate SMILES (BRCA1): O=C(NC1=CC=CC=C1)C2=NC=NC=N2
- Tool outcome: An ADME/QED computation was attempted but returned a validation error from the ADME tool. The input SMILES is syntactically valid; the failure appears due to an output formatting/validation issue in the tool, not the compound itself.
- Next step to obtain quantitative ADME/QED/RO5: Re-run the same SMILES once the tool output validation is fixed or allow me to re-attempt now. Expected outputs: QED, molecular weight, aLogP, HBD/HBA, PSA, rotatable bonds, aromatic rings, undesirable moieties.

4) Integrating results into a drug design strategy for selectivity, efficacy, and reduced toxicity
- Target selection by subtype:
  - HER2-positive disease: Design or optimize HER2-selective kinase inhibitors or ADCs.
    - Small-molecule TKIs: Optimize hinge-binding motifs for HER2, tune substituents to reduce EGFR off-target inhibition (common source of rash/diarrhea).
    - ADCs: Select linkers with controlled cleavage (e.g., cathepsin-cleavable) and payloads with appropriate potency and bystander effect; balance DAR to maintain PK and reduce off-target toxicity.
  - BRCA1/2-deficient disease: Focus on PARP1/2 selective inhibition (or ATR/Chk1 combinations).
    - Improve selectivity between PARP isoforms and minimize kinase cross-reactivity.
    - Reduce hERG risk via attenuating lipophilicity and tuning basicity; flag any anilide/aniline substructures and test for reactive metabolite formation.
- Medicinal chemistry gating rules (general):
  - Oral leads: Rule-of-Five compliant—MW ≤ 500, aLogP ~1.5–3.5, HBD ≤ 5, HBA ≤ 10, PSA ~65–120 Å², rotatable bonds ≤ 7–8.
  - CNS-sparing agents: PSA > 75 Å² and aLogP < 3.5 to limit BBB penetration if CNS toxicity is a concern.
  - Reduce polyaromatic load to mitigate off-target binding and toxicity; avoid structural alerts (e.g., nitro groups, Michael acceptors) unless justified.
- ADME optimization workflow:
  - Use computed QED and RO5 properties to gate series quickly; down-select compounds that meet oral exposure targets.
  - PK tuning: Adjust substituents to modulate logP/logD, reduce clearance (CYP-mediated), and balance plasma protein binding.
  - Safety screens early: hERG inhibition panel, CYP inhibition/induction, glutathione adduct screens, Ames test, reactive metabolite risk.
- Selectivity engineering:
  - HER2 TKIs: Structure-based design targeting HER2’s ATP pocket; exploit unique gatekeeper/interacting residues to improve selectivity against EGFR/ERBB3. Design covalent reversible or irreversible warheads only if justified; test for off-target kinases via kinome profiling.
  - PARP inhibitors: Maintain core pharmacophore for NAD+ pocket; tune substituents to favor PARP1/2 selectivity and minimize P-gp efflux. Consider reducing basicity to lower hERG risk while preserving potency.
- Clinical translation considerations:
  - Biomarker stratification: HER2 amplification/overexpression; BRCA1/2 germline or somatic mutation status; HRD scores.
  - Combination strategies: For BRCA-deficient tumors, consider PARP + ATR/Chk1 with careful hematologic toxicity monitoring; for HER2, antibody + TKI or ADC with dose/schedule optimization to reduce cardiotoxicity.
  - Go/No-Go criteria: Target potency ≤ 50 nM, HER2 vs EGFR selectivity ≥ 10x, hERG IC50 ≥ 10 µM, CYP time-dependent inhibition negative, oral bioavailability ≥ 30%, acceptable QED, and clean structural alerts.

What I can do next upon your go-ahead
- Re-run the ADME/QED calculation for the BRCA1 candidate SMILES once the tool output validation is cleared, and expand to any additional BRCA1 series you provide.
- Perform side-by-side ADME/QED comparisons across BRCA1 candidates to select the most developable lead.

- Assemble a concise decision matrix linking biomarker-defined subtypes (HER2+, BRCA-deficient) to the best modality (TKI, mAb, ADC, PARP inhibitor) with ADME/safety gates.

chat_message.content:
Thought:
- The user wants practical, comprehensive ways a company can protect its data from cyberattacks.
- Plan: Use the security_guidance tool to retrieve best-practice guidance, then provide a structured, concise checklist across key domains (governance, IAM, network, endpoint, apps/APIs, data protection, cloud, email/collab, backups/DR, logging/monitoring, vulnerability management, vendor risk, incident response, training). Include minimal config/code snippets (RBAC policy, TLS settings, parameterized queries), and compliance pointers (GDPR/CCPA/HIPAA). Emphasize least privilege, MFA, segmentation, zero trust, secure SDLC, continuous improvement.
- Tool: security_guidance with a comprehensive request.

Protecting company data from cyberattacks: a concise, actionable guide

Core principles
- Defense-in-depth: multiple controls across identity, network, endpoint, app, data, and monitoring.
- Zero Trust: verify explicitly, enforce least privilege, assume breach.
- Segmentation: separate networks, environments, and data domains; tightly control east-west traffic.
- Strong authentication: MFA across workforce, admins, and privileged actions; password managers and passkeys where possible.
- Secure SDLC: threat modeling, secure coding, SAST/DAST, code reviews, SBOM, pre-deploy security gates.
- Continuous improvement: patching, monitoring, exercises, audits, and metrics.

Governance and risk
- Establish security policies (access, encryption, logging, incident response, vendor risk).
- Maintain risk register; perform regular assessments (ISO 27001/2, NIST CSF).
- Data inventory and classification (public, internal, confidential, restricted).
- Assign ownership for systems and data; enforce change management (CAB).
- Define RTO/RPO objectives; align with business continuity plans.

Identity and access management (IAM)
- Enforce MFA (TOTP/app-based, hardware keys for admins).
- Least privilege via role-based access control (RBAC) and Just-In-Time elevation.
- Centralized SSO with conditional access; block legacy/weak protocols.
- Regular access reviews and automated deprovisioning on offboarding.
- Service accounts with scoped roles and short-lived credentials.

Example RBAC policy (AWS IAM, placeholder values)
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Sid": "AllowReadOnlyS3Bucket",
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": ["s3:GetObject", "s3:ListBucket"],
      "Resource": [
        "arn:aws:s3:::YOUR_BUCKET",
        "arn:aws:s3:::YOUR_BUCKET/*"
      ],
      "Condition": {
        "StringEquals": { "aws:PrincipalTag/role": "analyst" }
      }
    }
  ]
}

Network security
- Segment by environment (prod/dev), function (DB/app), and sensitivity; use firewalls and microsegmentation.
- Principle of default deny; allow only necessary ports and protocols.
- TLS for all services; enforce HSTS; restrict weak ciphers; certificate management and rotation.
- Secure VPN/ZTNA for remote access; disable split tunneling for sensitive roles.
- Protect DNS and email (SPF, DKIM, DMARC).
- DDoS protection and WAF for internet-facing apps; rate limiting and bot defenses.

Minimal TLS server config (Nginx)
server {
  listen 443 ssl http2;
  server_name example.com;

  ssl_protocols TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3;
  ssl_ciphers 'TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384:TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384';
  ssl_prefer_server_ciphers off;
  ssl_session_timeout 1d;
  ssl_session_cache shared:SSL:10m;
  ssl_stapling on;
  ssl_stapling_verify on;
  add_header Strict-Transport-Security "max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains" always;

  ssl_certificate /path/to/cert.pem;
  ssl_certificate_key /path/to/key.pem;

  location / {
    proxy_pass http://backend;
  }
}

Endpoint and mobile security
- EDR/XDR on endpoints; block known-bad behavior; isolate suspicious hosts.
- Full-disk encryption (BitLocker, FileVault) and device compliance policies.
- Mobile device management (MDM) with app allowlisting and data separation.
- Regular patching of OS, firmware, browsers; disable macros/unsigned scripts.
- USB/device control for sensitive environments.

Application and API security
- Secure coding: input validation, output encoding, parameterized queries, safe deserialization.
- Secrets management (vaults, KMS); never hardcode secrets.
- Authentication/authorization for APIs; scope tokens; rate limit and audit.
- SAST/DAST/IAST; dependency scanning and SBOM checks.
- Secure headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options).

Parameterized query example (Python psycopg2)
import psycopg2
conn = psycopg2.connect("host=DB_HOST dbname=DB_NAME user=DB_USER password=DB_PASSWORD sslmode=require")
with conn.cursor() as cur:
    cur.execute("SELECT * FROM customers WHERE id = %s", (customer_id,))
    rows = cur.fetchall()

Data protection
- Classification labels; handle restricted data with strongest controls.
- Encryption at rest: AES-256 in storage systems; managed keys via KMS/HSM.
- Encryption in transit: TLS 1.2+; mutual TLS for service-to-service where feasible.
- Key management: rotate keys, separation of duties, access logs, dual control for key material.
- Data minimization; anonymize/pseudonymize where possible; tokenization for payment data.

Cloud security (AWS/Azure/GCP)
- Use managed identities; avoid long-lived access keys; rotate automatically.
- Guardrails: SCPs (AWS), Azure Policies, Organization Policies (GCP).
- Private networking: VPC/VNet peering, PrivateLink/Private Service Connect; restrict public exposure.
- Storage controls: block public buckets, require object-level encryption, enforce bucket policies.
- Baselines: CIS Benchmarks; continuous posture management (CSPM) and workload protection (CWPP).

Email and collaboration security
- Enforce MFA and conditional access; disable legacy auth.
- Advanced phishing protection; attachment sandboxing and link safe browsing.
- DLP for email and collaboration suites; external sharing controls with expiry.
- Logs and audit trails for mailbox and file access.

Backups and disaster recovery
- 3-2-1 rule: 3 copies, 2 media, 1 offsite; include immutable backups (object lock/WORM).
- Test restores regularly; document RPO/RTO and run failover exercises.
- Isolate backup accounts/locations; separate credentials from production.

Logging, monitoring, and alerting
- Centralize logs (SIEM); collect auth events, admin actions, network flows, endpoint alerts, app/API logs.
- Define runbooks and alert thresholds; tune to reduce noise; maintain on-call rotation.
- Detect anomalies with UEBA; use threat intel; retain logs per compliance.

Vulnerability management and patching
- Asset inventory; automated vulnerability scanning (authenticated scans preferred).
- Patch cadence: critical within days; high within weeks; medium/low on schedule.
- Track CVEs; compensate with mitigations when patching is not possible.

Third-party and vendor risk
- Assess vendors’ security (SOC 2/ISO 27001); require DPAs/BAAs where applicable.
- Limit vendor access; segregate and monitor integrations; revoke when not needed.
- Review supply chain risks (software dependencies, CI/CD, artifact integrity).

Incident response
- Define IR plan: detection, triage, containment, eradication, recovery, postmortem.
- Keep contact trees and escalation paths updated; practice tabletop exercises.
- Evidence handling: immutable logs, chain of custody; coordinate with legal/compliance.

Employee training and phishing
- Regular security awareness; targeted training for high-risk roles.
- Phishing simulations with positive reinforcement; easy reporting mechanism.
- Clear policies on acceptable use, data handling, and shadow IT.

Compliance pointers
- GDPR: lawfulness of processing, data subject rights, DPIAs, data minimization, breach notification within 72 hours.
- CCPA/CPRA: consumer rights (access, delete), opt-out of sale/sharing, data inventory and notices.
- HIPAA: minimum necessary, BAAs, audit controls, encryption recommended, breach notification.

Data retention guidance
- Define retention schedules by data type and regulatory needs; minimize retention to business necessity.
- Automate lifecycle policies (e.g., delete/archive after N days); ensure backups follow retention and deletion requirements.
- Document legal holds; verify deletion through audit logs.

Quick checklist to start this quarter
- Enable MFA everywhere; hardware keys for admins.
- Inventory data and systems; classify data; restrict public exposure.
- Enforce least privilege and RBAC; review and remove stale access.
- Encrypt data at rest/in transit; verify TLS configs; rotate keys.
- Patch critical vulnerabilities; baseline CIS hardening.
- Deploy EDR/XDR; centralize logs to SIEM; set high-signal alerts.
- Test backups and restores; isolate backups; enable immutability.
- Run a phishing awareness campaign and IR tabletop exercise.

If you share your current environment (cloud provider, major apps, compliance obligations), I can tailor this into a prioritized 90-day roadmap.
